VI. others of the soldiery who attended him in the expedi- tion, against whom informations had been given that they were guilty of impiety in the affair of the Mysteries, and against some of them in that of the Mercuries. For, the Athenians, after the departure of the fleet, continu- ed to make as strict an inquisition as ever into the crimes committed in regard to the Mysteries, and also in regard to the Mercuries. What fort of persons the informers were was no part of their concern, but, in the height of jealousy, giving credit indiscriminately to all, through too great a deference to men of profligate and abandoned lives, they apprehended and threw into prison the most worthy citizens of Athens; esteeming it more prudent by pains and tortures to detect the fact, than that a person of irreproachable character, when once accused through the villany of an informer, should escape without the question.
